{{Infobox figure skater |name= Michael Weiss |image= Stars on Ice 2010 in Manchester (16).jpg |caption=Michael Weiss in 2010 |fullname= Michael Weiss |country= [[United States]] |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1976|8|2}} |birth_place= [[Washington, DC]] |residence= |height= {{convert|1.73|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |coach= [[Don Laws]] |choreographer= [[Lisa Thornton-Weiss]]
[[Peter Tchernyshev]] |skating club= Washington, FSC |retired= 2006 |combined total= 206.94 |combined date= [[Skate America|2003 Skate America]] |SP score= 73.85 |SP date= [[Skate America|2003 Skate America]] |FS score= 133.09 |FS date= [[Skate America|2003 Skate America]] |medaltemplates= {{MedalSport | Men's [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCountry | [[United States]] }} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Figure Skating Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[2000 World Figure Skating Championships|2000 Nice]] | [[2000 World Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[1999 World Figure Skating Championships|1999 Helsinki]] | [[1999 World Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Four Continents Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[2001 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2001 Salt Lake City]] | [[2001 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|Grand Prix Final]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[2003-2004 Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|2003–2004 Colorado Springs]] | [[2003-2004 Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[1994 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|1994 Colorado Springs]]|[[1994 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1993 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|1993 Seoul]]|[[1993 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} }} '''Michael Weiss''' (born August 2, 1976) is an [[United States|American]] former competitive and currently professional [[Figure skating|figure skater]]. He is a three-time [[United States Figure Skating Championships|national champion]] (1999, 2000, 2003) a two-time [[World Figure Skating Championships|World bronze medalist]] (1999, 2000), and two time Olympic team member. ==Personal life== Michael Weiss was born in [[Washington, DC]] and comes from an athletic family. Weiss's father, [[Greg Weiss|Greg]], was a gymnast on the 1964 Olympic team. Weiss's mother, Margie, was also a gymnast and national champion. His sister Geremi was a figure skater and junior national silver medalist; his other sister, Genna, was junior world diving champion. Weiss graduated from [[Wilbert Tucker Woodson High School]] in [[Fairfax, VA]]. Weiss also holds an associate's degree in [[business marketing]] from [[Prince George's Community College]]. He was a member of the [[Phi Theta Kappa]] Honor Society. Weiss and his wife Lisa have two children: Annie-Mae and Christopher. ==Career== Weiss began skating at the age of nine. He competed 19 consecutive times at the U.S. Championships. At the [[1997 United States Figure Skating Championships|1997 U.S. Championships]], he attempted to become the first American to land the [[Quad (figure skating)|quad]] [[Toe loop jump|toe loop]]. It was initially believed to have been successful but three hours after the competition, [[U.S. Figure Skating]] ruled the jump had been two-footed and did not ratify it. He was the first American to land a quadruple [[toe loop jump|toe loop]] in competition and has been coached by [[Don Laws]] and [[Audrey Weisiger]]. Weiss is the only skater to perform the Tornado, a backflip with a full twist, which he created. It is not allowed in competition, but it is a crowd favorite in exhibitions. Weiss turned professional in 2006. He toured with [[Stars On Ice]] and has competed in [[Ice Wars]]. ===Michael Weiss Foundation=== While still an eligible skater, Weiss started the Michael Weiss Foundation, which gives scholarships to up-and-coming figure skaters. Skaters who have received scholarships include Mirai Nagasu, [[Madison Hubbell|Madison]] and [[Keiffer Hubbell]], [[Daisuke Murakami (figure skater)|Daisuke Murakami]], and [[Christine Zukowski]]. ==Competitive highlights== ===Post-2000=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
